Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CDI-Type I: Computational Models for the Automatic Recognition of Non-Human Primate Social Behaviors

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to develop methods that will permit researchers to remotely and automatically monitor behavior of primates and other highly social animals. The PIs will collect behavioral data from cameras and microphones. They will then develop statistical models and computational algorithms to track the individuals in the group and to recognize facial expressions and vocalizations. Patterns in movements, expressions, and vocalizations will be used to develop behavior-identifying algorithms that will recognize different behaviors such as aggression, submission, grooming, eating and sleeping. The project is a collaboration between computer scientists and primatologists. A key element of this project is the observation that complex social interactions can often be regarded as being composed of sequences of elementary behaviors which occur frequently and consist of relatively simple and distinct gestures. Thus, the task of modeling complex social interactions can be broken down into two regimes ? elementary behaviors spanning short duration, and their stochastic sequences spanning relatively longer time duration.

Apart from advancing computational science, the new methods for recording behavior unobtrusively and analyzing them at a high data rate are likely to be of interest to behavioral ecologists, socio-biologists and neuroscientists in studies of primates and other highly social animals. With these new tools, scientists can study and understand behavior, for example, in the context of planning conservation efforts for threatened species, building accurate animal models for health research, and supporting animal husbandry decisions in zoos. The project will provide an extensive, annotated data repository and associated algorithms and will also fund graduate students who will gain hands-on training in all aspects of the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

This project was a collaborative effort between primate behavior scientists and engineers. The goal has been to develop an automatic behavior analysis system that could monotir primates in troops continuous throughout the day using video and audio recordsings. These can be analyzed using speech analysis and computer vision algorithms to extract information about primate mobility and interactions, leading to a determination of social hierarchy structure in a given troop. The project was collabortive and this PI's group was in charge of developing the video analysis algorithms to automatically detect primate activities and interactions. As a result of this project, we developed primate detection, identification, and tracking algorithms from multiview camera systems. The tracking results are also analyzed by the algorithms we developed further to determine mobility status and dependencies between primates, including behaviors such as chasing and avoiding that involve multiple primates. In data our team acquired, labeled, and analyzedm the algorithms we developed appear to be promising, but there remains room for further research and improvement, specifically to detect behaviors involving facial and body gestures of primates, which were not visible with sufficient resolution in our camera setup (which were HD, the best resolution available at the time, given budget constraints).

 

Broader Impacts:

The resulting algorithms can be useful for primate researchers who use these troops as animal models for humans in scientific experiments, in conservation efforts when trying to analyze and understand behaviors and interactions between individuals, and for conservation efforts.

This project supported attracted three PhD students at this PI's group, two of whom have already graduated and continued with their careers in industrial research laboratories; the third one is anticipated to graduate in 2015. One of these three students engaged, the primary PhD student who led the computer vision aspects, is a woman engineer and in addition to this project, she pursued additional training in engineering project management, and she is now a senior research scientist at a major research laboratory continuing to tackle problems of national interest with her computer vision expertise she developed through her experience and leadership, while pursuing her PhD degree funded by this project. The project, therefore, contributed significantly to the development of a diverse and capable workforce in this high tech area.

Note: As the PI writing this report was only in charge of the computer vision component of the project fundedunder the collaborative research mechanism, this report only points out contributions to science and society from this group's perspective. The public is invited to read the companion report from our collaborating institution.
